elements.content: A 2-fold interpenetrated microporous MOF [Ni2(C2O4)(L)2] n ·6nH2O (HL = 4,2′:4″,2′-terpyridine-4′-carboxylic acid) (1) was synthesized and structurally characterized. 1 has obvious 1D channels along the crystallographic a and c axes with a pore size of 5.7 to 6.9 Å. Topological analysis shows that the framework of 1 can be interpreted as a (3,4)-connected net with point symbol (63)(65·8). 1 exhibits high water and thermal stability, which is demonstrated by TGA, PXRD, and VT-PXRD. Additionally, the high temperature structure of 1′ (433 K) undoubtedly demonstrates the stability of the framework. More importantly, 1 shows high selectivities for CO2 over N2, H2, and CH4 at low pressure and 273 K.

elements.content: An new Ni(II) MOFs utilizing a new synthesized ligand, 4,2′:4″,2′-terpyridine-4′-carboxylic acid, exhibits good water and thermal stability. Single crystal X-ray characterization reveals that the structure is a 2D 2-fold interpenetrated framework with 1D channels along the crystallographic a and c axis. The gas sorption study demonstrates the MOF has the ability to selectively adsorb CO2 over CH4, H2 and N2.

elements.content: Recently, carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and storage (CCS) has emerged as a crucial research area in chemistry and material science since CO2 is believed to be the major greenhouse gas which causes global warming. However, one crucial technical challenge in CCS is the selective separation of CO2 from combustion gases containing nitrogen (N2) and other gases. On the other hand, natural gas, which is mainly composed of methane (CH4) along with other impurity such as CO2, is anticipated to be widely used to reduce the CO2 emission. Therefore, separation of CO2 from CH4 is essentially important as well. Currently, several approaches such as absorption with porous solids, amine scrubbing, and membrane have been applied for separation of CO2 from gas mixtures. Compared with chemical absorption, porous materials are potential candidates for CO2 selective separation since physical adsorption is an energetically more efficient process. As a new type of porous material, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention. High surface areas, open metal sites, adjustable and ordered structures, and low density endow them as good candidates for selective gas separation. Recent research shows that a lot of these crystalline materials exhibit excellent selectivity for CO2 adsorption. However, one big obstacle to the practical application of these porous materials is that most of them will gradually decompose in the presence of humidity. Since water vapor is usually mixed in natural gas and other industrial gases, high stability of adsorbents toward water vapor is required. Though many porous materials have been reported as adsorbents for the separation of CO2 from mixture gases, there are only a few examples demonstrating high ability to withstand humidity. Thus, design and synthesis of water stable MOFs with high CO2 selectivity is put on the schedule. In addition, since the separation CO2 from the flue gas is usually at high temperature, the high thermal stability of adsorbents is also required.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and storage (CCS) has emerged as a crucial research area in chemistry and material science since CO2 is believed to be the major greenhouse gas which causes global warming. However, one crucial technical challenge in CCS is the selective separation of CO2 from combustion gases containing nitrogen (N2) and other gases. On the other hand, natural gas, which is mainly composed of methane (CH4) along with other impurity such as CO2, is anticipated to be widely used to reduce the CO2 emission. Therefore, separation of CO2 from CH4 is essentially important as well. Currently, several approaches such as absorption with porous solids, amine scrubbing, and membrane have been applied for separation of CO2 from gas mixtures. Compared with chemical absorption, porous materials are potential candidates for CO2 selective separation since physical adsorption is an energetically more efficient process. As a new type of porous material, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention. High surface areas, open metal sites, adjustable and ordered structures, and low density endow them as good candidates for selective gas separation. Recent research shows that a lot of these crystalline materials exhibit excellent selectivity for CO2 adsorption. However, one big obstacle to the practical application of these porous materials is that most of them will gradually decompose in the presence of humidity. Since water vapor is usually mixed in natural gas and other industrial gases, high stability of adsorbents toward water vapor is required. Though many porous materials have been reported as adsorbents for the separation of CO2 from mixture gases, there are only a few examples demonstrating high ability to withstand humidity. Thus, design and synthesis of water stable MOFs with high CO2 selectivity is put on the schedule. In addition, since the separation CO2 from the flue gas is usually at high temperature, the high thermal stability of adsorbents is also required.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis, structure, and gas adsorption of a 2-fold interpenetrated microporous MOF [Ni2(C2O4)(L)2] n ·6nH2O (HL = 4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine-4′-carboxylic acid) (1), which exhibits high water and thermal stability and selective CO2 adsorption at ordinary pressure and 273 K.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis, structure, and gas adsorption of a 2-fold interpenetrated microporous MOF [Ni2(C2O4)(L)2] n ⋅6nH2O (HL = 4,2':6',4"-terpyridine-4'-carboxylic acid) (1), which exhibits high water and thermal stability and selective CO2 adsorption at ordinary pressure and 273 K.

elements.content: All reactants were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. 4,2′:6,′4″-Terpyridine-4′-carboxylic acid ligand was synthesized using the modified method according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The FT-IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1. 1H NMR spectra are obtained on a Burker AVANCE 400 (400 MHz) spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku Miniflex II X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Simulation of the PXRD spectrum was carried out by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reactants were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. 4,2':6,'4"-Terpyridine-4'-carboxylic acid ligand was synthesized using the modified method according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The FT-IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1. 1H NMR spectra are obtained on a Burker AVANCE 400 (400 MHz) spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku Miniflex II X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Simulation of the PXRD spectrum was carried out by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program.

elements.content: To a mixture of 4-acetylpyridine (19 mL, 168 mmol) and 2-furaldehyde (7 mL, 84 mmol) in 240 mL of ethanol was added NaOH (7.01 g, 175 mmol) in 7 mL of H2O (Scheme ). After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 35 mL of NH3·H2O (28–30%) was added and the resulting mixture mechanically stirred for 7 days. After filtering, white solid powder was obtained and washed with water and ethanol several times. Yield: 12.46 g (49.2%). The product was judged by solution 1H NMR to be of sufficient purity to be used in the following reaction without further purification. The above white solid (5.02 g) was added to a mixture of pyridine and water (300 mL, 2:1) and mechanically stirred at 100 °C. In this period, KMnO4 (60.16 g) was added in small portions to the above solution. After stirring for 7 days, the mixture was filtered and washed with hot water. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuum. The resulted residue was dissolved in water (80 mL) and the pH was adjusted to ca. 2.0 with concentrated hydrochloric acid (36.5%). The white precipitation was collected, washed several times with H2O, and dried in the vacuum. Yield: 3.82 g (82.1%). Anal. Calcd for C16H11O2N3 (M r = 277.28) (%): C, 69.31; H, 4.00; N, 15.15. Found (%): C, 69.13; H, 3.94; N, 15.10. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δH (ppm): 8.78 (4H, dd), 8.51 (2H, s), 8.25 (4H, dd). Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3069.8 (w), 1719.3 (s), 1599.5 (vs), 1405.3 (vs), 857.1 (w).

After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 35 mL of NH3⋅H2O (28-30%) was added and the resulting mixture mechanically stirred for 7 days. After filtering, white solid powder was obtained and washed with water and ethanol several times. Yield: 12.46 g (49.2%). The product was judged by solution 1H NMR to be of sufficient purity to be used in the following reaction without further purification. The above white solid (5.02 g) was added to a mixture of pyridine and water (300 mL, 2:1) and mechanically stirred at 100 °C. In this period, KMnO4 (60.16 g) was added in small portions to the above solution. After stirring for 7 days, the mixture was filtered and washed with hot water. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuum. The resulted residue was dissolved in water (80 mL) and the pH was adjusted to ca. 2.0 with concentrated hydrochloric acid (36.5%). The white precipitation was collected, washed several times with H2O, and dried in the vacuum. Yield: 3.82 g (82.1%). Anal. Calcd for C16H11O2N3 (M r = 277.28) (%): C, 69.31; H, 4.00; N, 15.15. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

A mixture of Ni(C2O4)⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol, 18 mg), HL (0.1 mmol, 28 mg), and 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 180 °C for 72 h. Then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C⋅h-1. Crystals of compound 1 were filtered and washed with hot water three times and dried in the air (yield 47% based on HL). Anal. Calcd for C17H16N3O7Ni (M r = 433) (%): C, 47.15; H, 3.72; N, 9.70. Found (%): C, 47.21; H, 3.79; N, 9.60. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1733.76 (w), 1655.13 (vs), 1616.63 (s), 1539.98 (vs), 1449.29 (s), 1318.25 (s), 1192.02 (w), 806.72 (w), 676.25 (m), 648.31 (w).

elements.content: Data collections were performed at 100 and 433 K respectively on an Agilent Super Nova CCD diffractometer equipped with multilayer mirror Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) by using an ω scan mode. Both the structures at 100 and 433 K were solved by direct methods, and all calculations were performed using the SHELXL package. At 100 K, all non-hydrogen atoms except the free water molecules in the structure (1) were refined anisotropically. For the free water molecules, no suitable peaks can be assigned as hydrogen atoms in the electron-density maps. In order to give detailed information on the framework, we removed these disordered water molecules using the “SQUEEZE” instruction and obtained the solvent-free structure 1 (after SQUEEZE). However, at 433 K in the structure (1′) no free water molecules can be assigned in the electron-density maps. In order to compare this high temperature framework with that of 1 (after SQUEEZE), we used the “SQUEEZE” instruction again and obtained 1′ (after SQUEEZE). The crystallographic data as well as the selected bond length of 1 (after SQUEEZE) and 1′ (after SQUEEZE) are listed in Table and Table .

X-ray Crystallography

Data collections were performed at 100 and 433 K respectively on an Agilent Super Nova CCD diffractometer equipped with multilayer mirror Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) by using an ω scan mode. Both the structures at 100 and 433 K were solved by direct methods, and all calculations were performed using the SHELXL package. At 100 K, all non-hydrogen atoms except the free water molecules in the structure (1) were refined anisotropically. For the free water molecules, no suitable peaks can be assigned as hydrogen atoms in the electron-density maps. In order to give detailed information on the framework, we removed these disordered water molecules using the "SQUEEZE" instruction and obtained the solvent-free structure 1 (after SQUEEZE). However, at 433 K in the structure (1') no free water molecules can be assigned in the electron-density maps. In order to compare this high temperature framework with that of 1 (after SQUEEZE), we used the "SQUEEZE" instruction again and obtained 1' (after SQUEEZE). The crystallographic data as well as the selected bond length of 1 (after SQUEEZE) and 1' (after SQUEEZE) are listed in Table and Table .

A Micromeritics (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 M System was used to measure gas adsorption. In order to remove guest water molecules in the framework, the fresh sample of 1 was soaked in methanol for 3 days, and then outgassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate dehydrated form prior to measurements. The N2 and H2 isotherm measurement was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. The CO2 adsorption measurements were done at 273 and 300 K in the same instrument. Additionally, N2, H2, and CH4 isotherms were measured in an ice/water bath. The CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1 was calculated by the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) model along with the pure component isotherm fits to determine the molar loadings in the mixture for specified partial pressures in the bulk gas phase.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Measurements

A Micromeritics (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 M System was used to measure gas adsorption. In order to remove guest water molecules in the framework, the fresh sample of 1 was soaked in methanol for 3 days, and then outgassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate dehydrated form prior to measurements. The N2 and H2 isotherm measurement was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. The CO2 adsorption measurements were done at 273 and 300 K in the same instrument. Additionally, N2, H2, and CH4 isotherms were measured in an ice/water bath. The CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1 was calculated by the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) model along with the pure component isotherm fits to determine the molar loadings in the mixture for specified partial pressures in the bulk gas phase.

elements.content: Reaction of Ni(C2O4)·2H2O with the organic ligand HL under hydrothermal conditions leads to green block crystals of compound 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 confirms that it crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and space group C2/m. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ni(II) cation, one 4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine-4′-carboxylic acid ligand, half of an oxalate ligand, and three free water molecules. The Ni(II) cation is in a distorted octahedral N2O4 coordination environment, which is completed by two nitrogen atoms from a L– ligand, two oxygen atoms of a carboxylate group, and two oxygen atoms of an oxalate ligand (Figure ). The Ni–N distances are in the range 2.036–2.071 Å, and the Ni–O distances are in the range 2.060–2.159 Å, which are all in great agreement with the reported lengths. Two adjacent Ni(II) cations are bridged by one oxalate ligand, with Ni···Ni separation of 5.60 Å. There is a mirror between these two Ni(II) cations, which is perpendicular to the Ni(II)···Ni(II) vector and through the two carbon atoms of the oxalate ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description

Reaction of Ni(C2O4)⋅2H2O with the organic ligand HL under hydrothermal conditions leads to green block crystals of compound 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 confirms that it crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system and space group C2/m. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Ni(II) cation, one 4,2':6',4"-terpyridine-4'-carboxylic acid ligand, half of an oxalate ligand, and three free water molecules. The Ni(II) cation is in a distorted octahedral N2O4 coordination environment, which is completed by two nitrogen atoms from a L- ligand, two oxygen atoms of a carboxylate group, and two oxygen atoms of an oxalate ligand (Figure ). The Ni-N distances are in the range 2.036-2.071 Å, and the Ni-O distances are in the range 2.060-2.159 Å, which are all in great agreement with the reported lengths. Two adjacent Ni(II) cations are bridged by one oxalate ligand, with Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni separation of 5.60 Å. There is a mirror between these two Ni(II) cations, which is perpendicular to the Ni(II)⋅⋅⋅Ni(II) vector and through the two carbon atoms of the oxalate ligand.

elements.content: The coordination environment of Ni(II) cations bridged by the oxalate group. The atoms are presented as 50% thermal ellipsoids. Symmetry codes: A, x, −y, z; B, x – 1/2, 1/2 – y, z; C, x, y, 1 + z.

elements.content: By the coordination of L ligands and oxalate groups to Ni(II) cations, it forms an independent 3D porous framework (Figure a). It should be noted that if the oxalate group, the L ligand, and the Ni(II) cation are treated as 2-connected, 3-connected, and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the present framework can also be interpreted topologically as a (3,4)-connected net with point (Schläfli) symbol (63)(65·8) (Figure b). The size of the largest channel along direction [0 0 1] is estimated as 15.29 Å × 16.87 Å by the separations of the opposite Ni(II) cations (considering the atomic van der Waals radii) and the oxygen atoms of the oxalate groups. There are two kinds of windows on this channel (see Figure S1 in the ). The small one is enclosed by four Ni(II) cations, two L ligands, and two oxalate groups, with the size of 2.10 Å × 8.39 Å (considering the atomic van der Waals radii). The big one is built from two Ni(II) cations and three L ligands, and the size is estimated as 8.15 Å × 8.39 Å × 9.5 Å (considering the atomic van der Waals radii). Especially, each channel communicates with six adjacent ones by two small windows and four big ones, which results in the 3D porous framework. However, because of no big guests to fill the large pores, two identical frameworks interpenetrate each other through four big windows to stabilize the whole structure (Figure S2 in the ). Due to the interpenetration, the pores along the crystallographic b axis are blocked. Thus only two types of 1D channels along the a (Figure a) and c axes (Figure b) remain, where the free water molecules exist as guests. Nevertheless, the total solvent accessible volume for 1 is estimated to be 35.2% calculated by the PLATON software. To evaluate the theoretical pore structure, the pore analysis tool Poreblazer was used to explore 1. The analysis results show that the pore system in 1 is percolated in one dimension with the pore limiting diameter of 5.73 Å and maximum pore diameter 6.91 of Å, and the accessible surface area per mass is 611 m2·g–1. Predictably, the pore in 1 with narrow pore size can be used for gas separation.

elements.content: The thermal and water stability of the porous materials is a key factor for separating CO2 from flue gas. To prove that the crystal structure of 1 is truly representative of the bulk materials, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments were carried out on the as-synthesized sample. As we can see in Figure , the XRPD experimental patterns of 1 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns. VT-PXRD patterns further indicate that the orders of the framework structure of complex 1 are retained at temperatures up to 300 °C (Figure , Figures S5 and S6 in the ). At the same time, to investigate the thermal stability of 1, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment was carried out in the temperature range 25–1000 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 (Figure S3 in the ). For 1, the weight loss of 12.36% in the temperature range 25–160 °C (calcd 12.47%) corresponds to three lattice water molecules, after which there is no obvious loss until about 310 °C. Most interestingly, the high temperature single-crystal X-ray structure of 1 (433 K, 1′) undoubtedly demonstrates the stability of the framework. In 1′, the framework is identical to that in 1, except that there are slight changes in the bond lengths and bond angles (Table ). Furthermore, the dihedral angles between the pyridyl rings in the ligand L have changed slightly at 100 and 473 K. At 100 K, the dihedral angles between the pyridyl rings in the ligand L are 11.89°, 40.92°, and 47.59°, while the corresponding dihedral angels are 6.63°, 42.70°, and 47.01° at 473 K. However, in 1′ no free water molecules can be assigned in the electron-density maps, which is in great agreement with the TGA. More important, 1 has good water stability. To test the water stability, the sample after adsorption experiment was immersed in the water at room temperature for 7 days and at 85 °C for 18 h. As shown in Figure , PXRD unambiguously verifies that 1 retains its structure. As we know, there are few examples of the structure of porous MOFs with thermal and water stability.
elements.clean_text:
Framework Stability

The thermal and water stability of the porous materials is a key factor for separating CO2 from flue gas. To prove that the crystal structure of 1 is truly representative of the bulk materials, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments were carried out on the as-synthesized sample. As we can see in Figure , the XRPD experimental patterns of 1 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns. VT-PXRD patterns further indicate that the orders of the framework structure of complex 1 are retained at temperatures up to 300 °C (Figure , Figures S5 and S6 in the ). At the same time, to investigate the thermal stability of 1, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment was carried out in the temperature range 25-1000 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 (Figure S3 in the ). For 1, the weight loss of 12.36% in the temperature range 25-160 °C (calcd 12.47%) corresponds to three lattice water molecules, after which there is no obvious loss until about 310 °C. Most interestingly, the high temperature single-crystal X-ray structure of 1 (433 K, 1') undoubtedly demonstrates the stability of the framework. In 1', the framework is identical to that in 1, except that there are slight changes in the bond lengths and bond angles (Table ). Furthermore, the dihedral angles between the pyridyl rings in the ligand L have changed slightly at 100 and 473 K. At 100 K, the dihedral angles between the pyridyl rings in the ligand L are 11.89°, 40.92°, and 47.59°, while the corresponding dihedral angels are 6.63°, 42.70°, and 47.01° at 473 K. However, in 1' no free water molecules can be assigned in the electron-density maps, which is in great agreement with the TGA. More important, 1 has good water stability. To test the water stability, the sample after adsorption experiment was immersed in the water at room temperature for 7 days and at 85 °C for 18 h. As shown in Figure , PXRD unambiguously verifies that 1 retains its structure. As we know, there are few examples of the structure of porous MOFs with thermal and water stability.

elements.content: Due to the highly stability and high accessible volume, 1 was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The as-synthesized 1 was activated by immersing in methanol (MeOH) for 3 days and then outgassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate dehydrated form 1a. The permanent porosity of 1a was established by N2 sorption experiments. The N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K exhibits typical “type I” adsorption behavior with maximum nitrogen uptake of 65 cm3·g–1 at 1 bar, indicating its microporous nature (Figure a). Thus, the corresponding pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption is 0.10 cm3·g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area is 266 m2·g–1, which is smaller than the theoretical value 611 m2·g–1. The significant difference of surface area is due to the narrow pore size, and the experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curve based on NLDFT model is shown in Figure b, which shows a maximum in the micropore range (ca. 7 Å). For those MOFs with ultramicropores (pore width <7 Å), only the adsorption isotherms of helium at 4.2 K can give more accurate pore information including pore size and specific surface area.

elements.content: H2 adsorption isotherms was recorded under atmospheric pressure, which also showed type I behavior with good reversibility. At 77 K and 1 bar, it had an uptake of 80 cm3·g–1 (Figure a), which is close to those of recently reported MOFs under the same conditions. To quantitatively compare the affinities to H2 molecules, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K (Figure a). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption (Q st) is calculated by the Clausius–Clapeyron equation, and the Q st at zero coverage is estimated to be 6.10 kJ·mol–1 (Figure b), higher than those of many famous porous materials, such as MOF-177 (4.4 kJ·mol–1) and MOF-5 (4.8 kJ·mol–1). It should be noted that both the N2 adsorption isotherm and the H2 adsorption isotherms show obvious hysteresis. The main reason is that the pore size in 1a is so small that there is strong binding affinity to H2 and N2.

elements.content: To further explore the potential properties on gas separation of 1a under ambient conditions, the adsorption isotherms of CO2, H2, N2, and CH4 for 1a at 273 K were measured, respectively (Figure ). The CO2 uptake value at 1 bar is 70 cm3·g–1 at 273 K, which is much higher than those of H2 (0.8 cm3·g–1), N2 (4.2 cm3·g–1), and CH4 (18.2 cm3·g–1). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1a under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted selectivities for equimolar CO2/CH4 gas mixture pairs in 1a are plotted in Figure . A remarkable point is that 1a shows very high CO2/CH4 selectivity (∼65), which can compare with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a Co(II) carborane-based MOF (∼47), Cu-BTC (∼8), MIL-53(Cr) (∼9), a mixed-ligand MOF (30), a carborane-based MOF with open metal sites (17), and a 2-D MOF with open metal sites (13). Coverage-dependent CO2 adsorption enthalpies of 1a were calculated according to the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. It shows that Q st exhibits a maximum of 30.8 kJ·mol–1 at initial coverage (Figure ). The high Q st for CO2 is benefited from the small pore size of 1, because the framework–CO2 interactions can be augmented in small pores.
elements.clean_text:
Selective CO2 Adsorption

To further explore the potential properties on gas separation of 1a under ambient conditions, the adsorption isotherms of CO2, H2, N2, and CH4 for 1a at 273 K were measured, respectively (Figure ). The CO2 uptake value at 1 bar is 70 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K, which is much higher than those of H2 (0.8 cm3⋅g-1), N2 (4.2 cm3⋅g-1), and CH4 (18.2 cm3⋅g-1). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1a under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted selectivities for equimolar CO2/CH4 gas mixture pairs in 1a are plotted in Figure . A remarkable point is that 1a shows very high CO2/CH4 selectivity (~65), which can compare with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a Co(II) carborane-based MOF (~47), Cu-BTC (~8), MIL-53(Cr) (~9), a mixed-ligand MOF (30), a carborane-based MOF with open metal sites (17), and a 2-D MOF with open metal sites (13). Coverage-dependent CO2 adsorption enthalpies of 1a were calculated according to the Clausius-Clapeyron equation. It shows that Q st exhibits a maximum of 30.8 kJ⋅mol-1 at initial coverage (Figure ). The high Q st for CO2 is benefited from the small pore size of 1, because the framework-CO2 interactions can be augmented in small pores.

elements.content: In summary, we report a 2-fold interpenetrated microporous framework [Ni2(C2O4)(L)2] n ·6nH2O, which has 1D channels along the crystallographic a and c axes. Topologically, the present framework can be interpreted topologically as a (3,4)-connected net with point (Schläfli) symbol (63)(65·8). It is worth noting that 1 has high CO2 selectivity. More importantly, 1 exhibits both high water and thermal stability, which is demonstrated by TGA, PXRD, VT-PXRD as well as the crystal structure at 433 K.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we report a 2-fold interpenetrated microporous framework [Ni2(C2O4)(L)2] n ⋅6nH2O, which has 1D channels along the crystallographic a and c axes. Topologically, the present framework can be interpreted topologically as a (3,4)-connected net with point (Schläfli) symbol (63)(65⋅8). It is worth noting that 1 has high CO2 selectivity. More importantly, 1 exhibits both high water and thermal stability, which is demonstrated by TGA, PXRD, VT-PXRD as well as the crystal structure at 433 K.

To a mixture of 4-acetylpyridine (19 mL, 168 mmol) and 2-furaldehyde (7 mL, 84 mmol) in 240 mL of ethanol was added NaOH (7.01 g, 175 mmol) in 7 mL of H2O (Scheme ). After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 35 mL of NH3·H2O (28–30%) was added and the resulting mixture mechanically stirred for 7 days. After filtering, white solid powder was obtained and washed with water and ethanol several times. Yield: 12.46 g (49.2%). The product was judged by solution 1H NMR to be of sufficient purity to be used in the following reaction without further purification. The above white solid (5.02 g) was added to a mixture of pyridine and water (300 mL, 2:1) and mechanically stirred at 100 °C. In this period, KMnO4 (60.16 g) was added in small portions to the above solution. After stirring for 7 days, the mixture was filtered and washed with hot water. The filtrate was evaporated in vacuum. The resulted residue was dissolved in water (80 mL) and the pH was adjusted to ca. 2.0 with concentrated hydrochloric acid (36.5%). The white precipitation was collected, washed several times with H2O, and dried in the vacuum. Yield: 3.82 g (82.1%). Anal. Calcd for C16H11O2N3 (M r = 277.28) (%): C, 69.31; H, 4.00; N, 15.15. Found (%): C, 69.13; H, 3.94; N, 15.10. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δH (ppm): 8.78 (4H, dd), 8.51 (2H, s), 8.25 (4H, dd). Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3069.8 (w), 1719.3 (s), 1599.5 (vs), 1405.3 (vs), 857.1 (w).

A mixture of Ni(C2O4)·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 18 mg), HL (0.1 mmol, 28 mg), and 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 180 °C for 72 h. Then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C·h–1. Crystals of compound 1 were filtered and washed with hot water three times and dried in the air (yield 47% based on HL). By the coordination of L ligands and oxalate groups to Ni(II) cations, it forms an independent 3D porous framework (Figure a). It should be noted that if the oxalate group, the L ligand, and the Ni(II) cation are treated as 2-connected, 3-connected, and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the present framework can also be interpreted topologically as a (3,4)-connected net with point (Schläfli) symbol (63)(65·8) (Figure b). The size of the largest channel along direction [0 0 1] is estimated as 15.29 Å × 16.87 Å by the separations of the opposite Ni(II) cations (considering the atomic van der Waals radii) and the oxygen atoms of the oxalate groups. There are two kinds of windows on this channel (see Figure S1 in the ). The small one is enclosed by four Ni(II) cations, two L ligands, and two oxalate groups, with the size of 2.10 Å × 8.39 Å (considering the atomic van der Waals radii). The big one is built from two Ni(II) cations and three L ligands, and the size is estimated as 8.15 Å × 8.39 Å × 9.5 Å (considering the atomic van der Waals radii). Especially, each channel communicates with six adjacent ones by two small windows and four big ones, which results in the 3D porous framework. However, because of no big guests to fill the large pores, two identical frameworks interpenetrate each other through four big windows to stabilize the whole structure (Figure S2 in the ). Due to the interpenetration, the pores along the crystallographic b axis are blocked. Thus only two types of 1D channels along the a (Figure a) and c axes (Figure b) remain, where the free water molecules exist as guests. Nevertheless, the total solvent accessible volume for 1 is estimated to be 35.2% calculated by the PLATON software. To evaluate the theoretical pore structure, the pore analysis tool Poreblazer was used to explore 1. The analysis results show that the pore system in 1 is percolated in one dimension with the pore limiting diameter of 5.73 Å and maximum pore diameter 6.91 of Å, and the accessible surface area per mass is 611 m2·g–1. Predictably, the pore in 1 with narrow pore size can be used for gas separation.

Adsorption Experiments

Due to the highly stability and high accessible volume, 1 was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The as-synthesized 1 was activated by immersing in methanol (MeOH) for 3 days and then outgassed overnight under vacuum at 120 °C to generate dehydrated form 1a. The permanent porosity of 1a was established by N2 sorption experiments. The N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K exhibits typical “type I” adsorption behavior with maximum nitrogen uptake of 65 cm3·g–1 at 1 bar, indicating its microporous nature (Figure a). Thus, the corresponding pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption is 0.10 cm3·g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area is 266 m2·g–1, which is smaller than the theoretical value 611 m2·g–1. The significant difference of surface area is due to the narrow pore size, and the experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curve based on NLDFT model is shown in Figure b, which shows a maximum in the micropore range (ca. 7 Å). For those MOFs with ultramicropores (pore width <7 Å), only the adsorption isotherms of helium at 4.2 K can give more accurate pore information including pore size and specific surface area.

H2 adsorption isotherms was recorded under atmospheric pressure, which also showed type I behavior with good reversibility. At 77 K and 1 bar, it had an uptake of 80 cm3·g–1 (Figure a), which is close to those of recently reported MOFs under the same conditions. To quantitatively compare the affinities to H2 molecules, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K (Figure a). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption (Q st) is calculated by the Clausius–Clapeyron equation, and the Q st at zero coverage is estimated to be 6.10 kJ·mol–1 (Figure b), higher than those of many famous porous materials, such as MOF-177 (4.4 kJ·mol–1) and MOF-5 (4.8 kJ·mol–1). It should be noted that both the N2 adsorption isotherm and the H2 adsorption isotherms show obvious hysteresis. The main reason is that the pore size in 1a is so small that there is strong binding affinity to H2 and N2.

Selective CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption

To further explore the potential properties on gas separation of 1a under ambient conditions, the adsorption isotherms of CO2, H2, N2, and CH4 for 1a at 273 K were measured, respectively (Figure ). The CO2 uptake value at 1 bar is 70 cm3·g–1 at 273 K, which is much higher than those of H2 (0.8 cm3·g–1), N2 (4.2 cm3·g–1), and CH4 (18.2 cm3·g–1). To evaluate the CO2/CH4 selectivity of 1a under mixture gas conditions with single-component isotherms, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) can be used to predict multicomponent adsorption behaviors. The predicted selectivities for equimolar CO2/CH4 gas mixture pairs in 1a are plotted in Figure . A remarkable point is that 1a shows very high CO2/CH4 selectivity (∼65), which can compare with some reported MOF materials under similar conditions, such as a Co(II) carborane-based MOF (∼47), Cu-BTC (∼8), MIL-53(Cr) (∼9), a mixed-ligand MOF (30), a carborane-based MOF with open metal sites (17), and a 2-D MOF with open metal sites (13). Coverage-dependent CO2 adsorption enthalpies of 1a were calculated according to the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. It shows that Q st exhibits a maximum of 30.8 kJ·mol–1 at initial coverage (Figure ). The high Q st for CO2 is benefited from the small pore size of 1, because the framework–CO2 interactions can be augmented in small pores.
